Body: I.e., everyone who maliciously tries to uncover real or imaginary faults in others.

This repetitive interpolation is necessary because the
				blameworthy attitude spoken of in verses {2-3} obviously
				belongs to a category entirely different from the two
				mentioned in verse {1}.

This is a metonym for the tendency to attribute an almost
				"religious" value to the acquisition and possession of
				material goods and facilities - a tendency which
				precludes man from giving any real importance to
				spiritual considerations (cf. note [1] on  102:1 ). My
				rendering of 'addadahu in the preceding verse as "[he]
				counts it a safeguard" is based on Jawhari's explanation
				of this term.
Al-hutamah - one of several metaphors for the\n\t\t\t\totherworldly suffering comprised within the concept of\n\t\t\t\t"hell" (see note [33] on {15:43-44}.
I.e., originating in their hearts - thus clearly alluding\n\t\t\t\tto the spiritual nature of the "fire" in the sinners'\n\t\t\t\tbelated realization of their guilt.
Lit., "in extended columns", i.e., overwhelming with\n\t\t\t\tdespair.
